There are several factors that contributed to the fact that minimalist music did not gain as much mainstream popularity as other genres during the 1960s and 70s.

Firstly, minimalist music was often experimental and unconventional in its form and structure, which made it difficult for a wider audience to appreciate and relate to. The repetitive nature of the music may also have been perceived as monotonous or lacking in variety by some listeners.

Secondly, the minimalist movement was not part of the established music industry and the composers often worked independently from traditional venues and institutions. This made it harder for them to gain recognition and reach a wider audience.

Thirdly, the minimalist movement was still relatively new and developing during this era, and it took some time for the music to gain wider appreciation and recognition. This began to change in the 1980s and 90s, when minimalist music began to be integrated into film and television soundtracks, and some minimalist composers gained wider recognition.

Overall, the minimalist movement was more focused on experimental and avant-garde practices, rather than mainstream commercial success, which contributed to its limited popularity in the music industry during that era.
